results.title: The Internet’s Loop of Action and Reaction Is Worsening
results.abstract: Wouldn’t it have been kind of a pleasant dream world, in these overheated last few weeks, to have lived free of social media?

results.title: Why Donald Trump’s Call to ‘Close Up’ the Internet Is Science Fiction
results.abstract: Donald Trump suggested asking Bill Gates, the Microsoft co-founder, for help in shutting down the Internet in some areas. But the worldwide computer network was designed to thwart such an attempt.

results.title: Yahoo to Keep Alibaba Stake but Spin Off Core Businesses
results.abstract: Yahoo has decided to retain its Alibaba stake and will instead look at transferring its other assets, including Yahoo Japan, into a new company.

multimedia.caption: With Marissa Mayer as chief executive, Yahoo has made dozens of acquisitions and added original video and magazine-style content. But its core Internet operations are still struggling.
multimedia.copyright: Max Whittaker for The New York Times

results.title: Marissa Mayer Has a Year to Fulfill Yahoo’s Potential
results.abstract: With Yahoo’s one billion users and revenue of nearly $5 billion, investors would be salivating if Yahoo were a start-up, not a faded Internet company.

results.title: Possible Suitors for Yahoo
results.abstract: Barry Diller’s IAC/InterActive could be a logical home for its Internet businesses, as might Verizon, owner of AOL.

multimedia.caption: Barry Diller’s IAC/InterActive, which spun off a variety of dating websites, could be a logical home for Yahoo.

results.title: Tech Shares Slip as Market Extends Losing Streak
results.abstract: Shares of Dow Chemical and DuPont were up after reports that the companies were discussing a combination.

results.title: Volkswagen Terms One Emissions Problem Smaller Than Expected
results.abstract: VW said it overstated things when it announced it had misled the public about fuel economy and greenhouse gas emissions for 800,000 European vehicles.

multimedia.caption: A Volkswagen assembly line in Wolfsburg, Germany. Matthias Müller, the automaker's chief executive, will hold a news conference on Thursday.

results.title: Blendle, a Journalism Payments Start-Up, Targets a U.S. Start Date
results.abstract: The company allows small payments for articles and has half a million subscribers in Germany and the Netherlands.

results.title: Study Finds Director Pay Rising Sharply
results.abstract: Among industries, pay to serve on the boards of energy and mining companies is the highest. Finance is the second lowest, after utility companies, Equilar says.

results.title: ‘Happy Birthday’ Copyright Case Reaches a Settlement
results.abstract: If the settlement is approved, the popular song will enter the public domain and the publisher will not collect royalties.

results.title: First Dengue Fever Vaccine Approved by Mexico
results.abstract: The vaccine, called Dengvaxia, has been developed by Sanofi. Dengue fever can cause high temperature and intense joint and muscle pain.

multimedia.caption: A young woman with dengue fever is watched over by her mother in a Pakistani hospital. An estimated 50 million to 100 million people a year are sickened by the disease.

results.title: Dow Chemical and DuPont Are Said to Be in Merger Talks
results.abstract: Two of the biggest and oldest chemical companies in the United States, each with a market value of roughly $60 billion, could become the world’s second-largest chemical maker in terms of revenue.
results.byline: By LESLIE PICKER and MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

multimedia.caption: DuPont's Chestnut Run Plaza office near Wilmington. The company is in merger talks with Dow Chemical.

results.title: Douglas Tompkins, 72, North Face Founder, Dies in Kayaking Accident
results.abstract: A hitchhiking encounter led to marriage and a store in San Francisco. Mr. Tompkins also founded the Esprit clothing brand before becoming a wealthy conservationist in South America.
results.byline: By RACHEL ABRAMS and ASHLEY SOUTHALL

results.title: 6 Companies Make Market Debut in China After 5-Month Hiatus
results.abstract: Stock in all six companies surged by their daily limit of 44 percent, a typical increase for listings in China.

results.title: U.S. Wholesale Inventories Shrink, Hinting at More Anemic Growth
results.abstract: The Commerce Department said that wholesale inventories slipped 0.1 percent in October as sluggish sales have given businesses little incentive to restock.

results.title: AccorHotels to Raise Luxury Profile With $2.9 Billion Acquisition
results.abstract: AccorHotels is buying the owner of luxury hotels including London's Savoy and New York's Plaza, in a cash-and-share deal worth $2.9 billion (1.9 billion pounds) that will also raise the U.S. profile of Europe's largest hotel group.

results.title: C. Gerald Fraser, Longtime Reporter for The Times, Dies at 90
results.abstract: Mr. Fraser, one of the first black reporters hired by The Times, covered courts, culture and the landmark presidential campaign of Shirley Chisholm.

results.abstract: After he was fired from the network, Mr. Taylor became the founding president of a premium cable channel that was the predecessor of A&E.

results.title: Walmart’s Imports From China Displaced 400,000 Jobs, a Study Says
results.abstract: Walmart’s Chinese imports amounted to at least $49 billion in 2013, according to the study, which was based on trade and labor data.

results.title: Australian Police Raid Home of Man Said to Be Likely Creator of Bitcoin
results.abstract: The police said the raid was for a tax investigation, and a spokesman denied any connection to the Bitcoin reports.
results.byline: By MICHELLE INNIS and AUSTIN RAMZY

results.title: Afghanistan Hopes W.T.O. Membership Can Reboot Its Battered Economy
results.abstract: Optimists view the trade body’s seal of approval as a potential lift for the war-ravaged country whose chief export is opium and main “import” is international aid.

multimedia.caption: Afghan farmers harvesting opium sap in a poppy field near Jalalabad. Afghanistan “remains a poor, fragile state far from self-reliance,” an International Monetary Fund report said.

results.title: For Immigrants, America Is Still More Welcoming Than Europe
results.abstract: While its policies are often hostile, the United States is more successful than Europe at integrating immigrants into the national fabric.

results.title: Tech Toys to Inspire a Child’s Imagination
results.abstract: These interactive toys incorporate various technologies including virtual reality, animation and robotics.

results.title: Video Feature: Apps, Like Elves, Help Make the Season Bright
results.abstract: Apps for creating animated video during the holidays, and for help thinking of gift ideas, organizing lists, tracking Santa and donating to charities.

results.title: A Bad Review Is Forever: How to Counter Online Complaints
results.abstract: For small businesses that can live or die by word of mouth, an array of strategies helps track and respond to online ratings.

results.abstract: Apple’s Smart Keyboard was designed for its newer, larger iPad Pro tablet, but there are cheaper alternatives.

results.title: When Seeking Better C.D. Yields Can Be Costly
results.abstract: Consumers watching interest rates should also watch out for stiff penalties if they decide to withdraw money from certificates of deposit early.

results.title: Bill Gates Takes On Climate Change With Nudges and a Powerful Rolodex
results.abstract: Mr. Gates, acting as an envoy between the worlds of business and policy, has pressed global leaders and tech billionaires to team up on clean technology.
results.byline: By CORAL DAVENPORT and NICK WINGFIELD
des_facet: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

multimedia.caption: Bill Gates stood with world leaders in November at the climate change conference in France. From left, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada, Mr. Gates, President Obama, President François Hollande of France and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India.

results.title: Private Equity Fees Are Sky-High, Yes, but Look at Those Returns
results.abstract: Perhaps we should balance the criticism of private equity firms for excessive fees with the great demand for private equity investments and the important role they play.
